Summarize this article for a 10 years old Traditional medicine (also known as indigenous medicine or folk medicine) comprises medical aspects of [traditional knowledge](/en/Traditional_knowledge) that developed over generations within the [folk beliefs](/en/Folk_belief) of various societies, including [indigenous peoples](/en/Indigenous_peoples), before the era of modern [medicine](/en/Medicine). The [World Health Organization](/en/World_Health_Organization) (WHO) defines traditional medicine as "the sum total of the knowledge, skills, and practices based on the theories, beliefs, and experiences indigenous to different cultures, whether explicable or not, used in the maintenance of health as well as in the prevention, diagnosis, improvement or treatment of physical and mental illness". [[1]](#cite_note-WHO-1) Traditional medicine is often contrasted with [scientific medicine](/en/Evidence-based_medicine). In some [Asian](/en/Asia) and [African](/en/Africa) countries, up to 80% of the population relies on traditional medicine for their [primary health care](/en/Primary_health_care) needs. When adopted outside its traditional culture, traditional medicine is often considered a form of [alternative medicine](/en/Alternative_medicine). [[1]](#cite_note-WHO-1) Practices known as traditional medicines medicine include [herbalism](/en/Herbalism), [ethnomedicine](/en/Ethnomedicine), [ethnobotany](/en/Ethnobotany), and [medical anthropology](/en/Medical_anthropology).
